elements.content: Naphtheledicarboxylato ((NDC2–) bridged coordination polymers (CPs) along with (E)-1-methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole (ClPai-Me) coordination to Co­(II), [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1), and to Zn­(II), [Zn­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (2), have been characterized. In the single crystal X-ray structure of 1, ClPai-Me chelates to the Co­(II) ion by N­(azo) and N­(imidazolyl), whereas in compound 2, it acts as a monodentate N­(imidazolyl) donor to the Zn­(II) ion. The coordination atmosphere around Co­(II) in the 1 ion is distorted octahedral CoN2O4, whereas in the case of 2, it is distorted square pyramidal ZnNO4. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit the right-handed (P) and left-handed (M) one-dimensional helical chain. NDC–2 is serving as a bridge between two M­(II) ions to constitute μ-NDC and four M­(II) ions to construct μ4-NDC to assemble three-dimensional polymers. Upon UV light (369 nm) irradiation, compound 2 shows trans-to-cis isomerization of -NN–C6H4–Cl-p both in the solid and solution state but 1 remains silent. Prolonged light irradiation in the solid state (film phase) does not change the coordinated ClPai-Me in complexes 1 and 2, whereas the free stage of ClPai-Me undergoes photoreduction of the −NN– bond and forms azo radicals with a concomitant permanent color change. The persistence of the radical has been characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy in the solid state at g = 2.009. The effective magnetic moment of 1 is 4.17 μB at 300 K, Co­(II) ion of S = 3/2.

Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit the right-handed (P) and left-handed (M) one-dimensional helical chain. elements.content: Two novel Co­(II) and Zn­(II) helical coordination polymers (CPs) bridged by 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acetate (NDC−2) in collaboration with a photoswitchable ligand, (E)-2-((4-chlorophenyl)­diazenyl)-1-methyl-imidazole (ClPai-Me), are characterized. Interestingly, Zn-CP only undergoes light induced trans−cis isomerization about -NN-C6H4-Cl both in the solution phase and solid phase.
elements.clean_text: Two novel Co(II) and Zn(II) helical coordination polymers (CPs) bridged by 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acetate (NDC-2) in collaboration with a photoswitchable ligand, (E)-2-((4-chlorophenyl)diazenyl)-1-methyl-imidazole (ClPai-Me), are characterized. Interestingly, Zn-CP only undergoes light induced trans-cis isomerization about -NN-C6H4-Cl both in the solution phase and solid phase.

elements.content: The coordination polymers (CPs) are useful in devices of gas storage and gas separation, catalysis, drug delivery, electrical conductivity, sensing studies, energy strategy, and oxygen balance. Interests to the design of task-specific materials as a response to external stimuli, such as light, heat, magnetic field, or mechanical effects are of the highest importance. However, the optical stimulation to CPs is of the most effective because light is one of the most simple and practical signals, and the material may absorb at a specific wavelength, and subsequent performance, such as emission of longer wavelength, chemical reaction, energy or electron transfer, sensitization, or transformation may have many applications. An optical signal is very faithful to the user, and switching off the source causes an immediate turn off of the optical signal. Hence, it does not induce any change of material structure and may be remote controlled over long distances, which is useful in ultra-high-density optical memory, optical information storage, light control, and optical switches. The photoactive CP materials, either in bulk solution, incorporated in suitable matrices, or on surfaces, may be used for various applications, such as molecular nanomachines, photochromic glasses, high-capacity undistorted data storage devices, etc. The photoresponsive materials are sensitive to the nature of substituents (steric and electronic effects), the strength of covalent/noncovalent interactions, and external factors, such as solvent (polarity, viscosity, dipole moment, etc.) and the presence of innocent (to be chemically noninteracting) and noninnocent (chemically interacting) ions or molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The coordination polymers (CPs) are useful in devices of gas storage and gas separation, catalysis, drug delivery, electrical conductivity, sensing studies, energy strategy, and oxygen balance. Interests to the design of task-specific materials as a response to external stimuli, such as light, heat, magnetic field, or mechanical effects are of the highest importance. However, the optical stimulation to CPs is of the most effective because light is one of the most simple and practical signals, and the material may absorb at a specific wavelength, and subsequent performance, such as emission of longer wavelength, chemical reaction, energy or electron transfer, sensitization, or transformation may have many applications. An optical signal is very faithful to the user, and switching off the source causes an immediate turn off of the optical signal. Hence, it does not induce any change of material structure and may be remote controlled over long distances, which is useful in ultra-high-density optical memory, optical information storage, light control, and optical switches. The photoactive CP materials, either in bulk solution, incorporated in suitable matrices, or on surfaces, may be used for various applications, such as molecular nanomachines, photochromic glasses, high-capacity undistorted data storage devices, etc. The photoresponsive materials are sensitive to the nature of substituents (steric and electronic effects), the strength of covalent/noncovalent interactions, and external factors, such as solvent (polarity, viscosity, dipole moment, etc.) and the presence of innocent (to be chemically noninteracting) and noninnocent (chemically interacting) ions or molecules.

elements.content: Azobenzene undergoes optically stimulated reversible cis/trans isomerization. The conformational change is coupled with a significant change of volume; trans-azobenzene is linear, rod-shaped (length, 9 Å), and less space demanding, whereas cis-azobenzene (length, 5.5 Å) is bent shaped and demands a larger space. A combination of such kind of smart moieties in the CPs or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) may construct a fascinating and challenging class of materials. The conformational change of azo benzene in the MOF cavity shows light-stimulated sorption behavior, such as the absorption of a significant amount of CO2 at dark, and upon light irradiation, CO2 is released.

A combination of such kind of smart moieties in the CPs or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) may construct a fascinating and challenging class of materials. The conformational change of azo benzene in the MOF cavity shows light-stimulated sorption behavior, such as the absorption of a significant amount of CO2 at dark, and upon light irradiation, CO2 is released.

elements.content: In the search of new azo functionalized photochromes, 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)­imidazoles exhibit potential optical stimulated structural isomerization and have been employed to examine the effect of substituents of different electronic activity, nature of solvent, presence of foreign innocent molecules and micelles, coordination with metal ions preferably d8 (low spin) and d10 electronic structure. This has motivated us to synthesize an arylazoimidazole bonded coordination polymer. Optically induced structural change of 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)­imidazoles (RaaiR / ) (photochromism, ) has been examined vastly in the solution phase. However, the inclusion of a photoswitching molecule, azoimidazole motif to organic linker, or binding to the metal node as an integrated part of CPs (film phase) has not been studied. Development of such an optically sensitive new class of switching material is the subject of the present research interest.

elements.clean_text: 1  Photochromism of 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)imidazole

elements.content: In this study, the ClPai-Me ((E),1-methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole), a photochrome, is coordinated to M­(II) (Co­(II), Zn­(II)) along with a coordination polymer forming ligand, 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2NDC) to synthesize a high spin Co­(II) coordination polymer, [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1) and [Zn­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (2) (). Although a large number of 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)­imidazoles (RaaiR/) are known, the Cl-substituted arylazo motif in ClPai-Me crystallizes in a metal complex in a suitable shape and size; so, the ClPai-Me derivative has been synthesized. In 1, ClPai-Me serves as N­(azo), N­(imidazolyl) chelator to Co­(II), and in 2, it acts as a monodentate N­(imidazolyl) donor to Zn­(II) and assists π-interactions to improve dimensional stability. The structures of the complexes are supported by single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements. Photoresponsive properties are examined in solution and in the solid state (film phase). As far as the literature is concerned, this is the first example of CPs of Co­(II) and Zn­(II) ions attached to an arylazoimidazole photochoromic motif with 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate. The arylazoimidazole performs conformational isomerization by light-stimulated trans–cis isomerization and a thermal process assists the cis–trans conversion, which has been authenticated by UV–vis spectroscopy in both solution and solid state. The bonded ClPai-Me in compound 2 shows active photochromism but 1 remains inert. Solid phase light irradiation to ClPai-Me in the free ligand phase shows azo radical formation (EPR active), while in complexes (1 and 2) no such effect is observed. The redox properties of these compounds were obtained by cyclic voltammetry. The magnetic behavior of 1 was authenticated by SQUID.

The Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellet) were taken on a PerkinElmer RX1 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Phillips PANalytical diffractometer Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature, with a scan speed of 2 min–1 and a step size of 0.02 in 2θ.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

Reagents and solvents were commercially available (Sigma-Aldrich) and were used as received. The Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellet) were taken on a PerkinElmer RX1 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Phillips PANalytical diffractometer Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at room temperature, with a scan speed of 2 min-1 and a step size of 0.02 in 2θ.

elements.content: The polymer films were prepared on quartz supports by casting from tetrahydrofuran solution by mixing equivalent portions of a 5 wt % polymer solution (polyvinyl chloride, Aldrich, MW = 43000) and a 0.2 wt % solution of low-mass compound 2 and ClPai-Me. The films were dried under reduced pressure at 50 °C for 24 h. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 25–600 °C on a SDT Q600 TG-DTA analyzer under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Magnetic properties were investigated using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL superconducting quantum interference device magnetometer (SQUID) at an applied field 0.5 T in a temperature range 5–300 K. The diamagnetic correction was carried out by using Pascal constants. A Bruker (AC) 400 MHz FT-NMR spectrometer using TMS as an internal standard was available for 1H spectra recording. A solar simulator ISS P110 Lamp power supply was used as the light source (λ, 360 nm). EPR data were collected using a Magnettech GmbH Mini Scope MS400 spectrometer.

The films were dried under reduced pressure at 50 °C for 24 h. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 25-600 °C on a SDT Q600 TG-DTA analyzer under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Magnetic properties were investigated using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL superconducting quantum interference device magnetometer (SQUID) at an applied field 0.5 T in a temperature range 5-300 K. The diamagnetic correction was carried out by using Pascal constants. A Bruker (AC) 400 MHz FT-NMR spectrometer using TMS as an internal standard was available for 1H spectra recording. A solar simulator ISS P110 Lamp power supply was used as the light source (λ, 360 nm). EPR data were collected using a Magnettech GmbH Mini Scope MS400 spectrometer.

elements.content: Two good-shaped single crystals (0.361 × 0.225 × 0.083 mm) (1) and (0.215 × 0.115 × 0.081 mm) (2) were used for data collection via Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Least squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl range −18 ≤ h ≤ 18, −24 ≤ k ≤ 24, −19 ≤ l ≤ 19 (1) and −18 ≤ h ≤ 18, −25 ≤ k ≤ 25, −20 ≤ l ≤ 20 (2) were used to determine the unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The collected data (I > 2σ­(I)) were integrated using SAINT program, and the absorption correction were made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were carried out using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to ride on the respective carbon or nitrogen atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic displacement of their parent atom in all cases. All calculations were carried out using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 program. Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Solution

Two good-shaped single crystals (0.361 × 0.225 × 0.083 mm) (1) and (0.215 × 0.115 × 0.081 mm) (2) were used for data collection via Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer, having graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Least squares refinements of all reflections within the hkl range -18 ≤ h ≤ 18, -24 ≤ k ≤ 24, -19 ≤ l ≤ 19 (1) and -18 ≤ h ≤ 18, -25 ≤ k ≤ 25, -20 ≤ l ≤ 20 (2) were used to determine the unit cell parameters and crystal-orientation matrices. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The collected data (I > 2σ(I)) were integrated using SAINT program, and the absorption correction were made with SADABS. Full matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were carried out using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were constrained to ride on the respective carbon or nitrogen atoms with isotropic displacement parameters equal to 1.2 times the equivalent isotropic displacement of their parent atom in all cases. All calculations were carried out using SHELXL 97, SHELXS 97, PLATON 99, and ORTEP-3 program. Crystal data and experimental details for data collection and structure refinement are reported in .

elements.clean_text:
Photometric Measurements

Absorption spectra were taken with a PerkinElmer Lambda 25 UV-vis spectrophotometer in a 1 × 1 cm quartz optical cell maintained at 25 °C. The light source of ISS P110 Lamp power supply was used as an excitation light.

elements.content: The rates of thermal cis-to-trans isomerization were collected by monitoring absorption changes for a cis-rich solution kept in the dark at constant temperatures (T) in the range from 298 to 313 K. The Arrhenius plot, ln k = ln A – E a/RT (k, the measured rate constant; R, the gas constant, and T, temperature) is used to calculate the activation energy (E a), the activation free energy (ΔG *), activation entropy (ΔS *), and the frequency factor (A) from : Δ G * = E a − RT − T Δ S * and Δ S * = [ ln ⁡ A − 1 − ln ( k B T / h ) / R ] where k B and h are Boltzmann’s and Planck’s constants, respectively.

(E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole (ClPai-Me) had been synthesized and characterized by literature method.

[Co­(∝-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(∝<sub>4</sub>-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(ClPai-Me)]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

ClPai-Me (0.1 mmol), H2NDC (0.1 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) were mixed in a 30 mL vial. Then a mixed solution (9 mL) of methanol/water/DMF was added at an equivalent ratio (1:1:1). The vial was capped well and heated to 100 °C for 72 h, and cooling at the rate of 5 °C/h. The mother liquor was decanted, and the crystals were washed with hexane (15 mL) thrice. Dark black-colored crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air for X-ray study (10 min). Yield: 33.9 mg (∼67%). [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1) was isolated by filtration. Microanalytical data for (C44H31Cl2Co2N8O9)∞ (1): C, 52.61; H, 3.11; N, 11.15, Found: C, 52.56; H,3.03; N 11.09, IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1609 νas(COO–), 1331 νs(COO–), and 1396 ν­(-NN-) (Supporting Information, Figure S1). The TGA plot of compound 1 confirmed the number of crystallization water molecules, and it is moderately stable up to 330 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 as-synthesized are added in Figure S3.

elements.content: (E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole (ClPai-Me) has been synthesized and characterized by a literature method. It has two eligible donor centers, N­(azo) and N­(imidazolyl). Solvothermal synthesis using ClPai-Me, H2NDC, and Co­(NO3)2­·6H2O/Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O has isolated coordination polymers. The structures of [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1) and [Zn­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (2) are confirmed by single crystal X-ray structure determination. Complexes 1 and 2 both crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4, and the structure is shown in . In 1, each Co­(II) ion adopts a CoN2O4 distorted octahedral geometry by chelating two nitrogen donor centers of ClPai-Me (N­(azo) and N­(imidazolyl)) and four carboxylato-O centers from three naphthyl-2,6-dicarboxylates (NDC). Two NDC–2 molecules act as monodentate carboxylato-O donors, and a third NDC–2 is a carboxylato-O,O chelator to Co­(II) and −COO– of another end of the linker serves as a bridging agent to generate a polymeric framework (, ). Thus, a coordination polymer is constituted by bridging two adjacent Co­(II) centers by two chelated carboxylate-O,O of NDC–2 (μ) and bridging four adjacent Co­(II) centers by four carboxylate-O of second NDC–2 (μ4) (Figure S7), which leads to generate a chair form Co2O4C2 repeating unit. Thus, an eight-member Co2O4C2 distorted chair geometry repeats throughout the polymer (). The Co–N­(imidazolyl) bond distance is 2.041(3) Å, which is comparable to the reported structure of Co-arylazoimidazole complexes. The Co–N­(azo) bond length 2.376(3) Å is longer than Co–N­(imidazolyl), which indicates that Co­(II) prefers to bind N­(imidazolyl), and this is very common in biology. The Co–O bond lengths vary noticeably in the bridging partner: the NDC bridged Co4 motif shows 2.008(3) and 2.016(3) Å, whereas the carboxylato chelated Co2 motif shows 2.235(3) and 2.128(3) Å (). In the chelated motif, both steric and angular strains may cause elongation of the bond length.

Results and Discussion

(E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)imidazole (ClPai-Me) has been synthesized and characterized by a literature method. It has two eligible donor centers, N(azo) and N(imidazolyl). Solvothermal synthesis using ClPai-Me, H2NDC, and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O/Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O has isolated coordination polymers. The structures of [Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (1) and [Zn(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (2) are confirmed by single crystal X-ray structure determination. Complexes 1 and 2 both crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with Z = 4, and the structure is shown in . In 1, each Co(II) ion adopts a CoN2O4 distorted octahedral geometry by chelating two nitrogen donor centers of ClPai-Me (N(azo) and N(imidazolyl)) and four carboxylato-O centers from three naphthyl-2,6-dicarboxylates (NDC). Two NDC-2 molecules act as monodentate carboxylato-O donors, and a third NDC-2 is a carboxylato-O,O chelator to Co(II) and -COO- of another end of the linker serves as a bridging agent to generate a polymeric framework (, ). Thus, a coordination polymer is constituted by bridging two adjacent Co(II) centers by two chelated carboxylate-O,O of NDC-2 (μ) and bridging four adjacent Co(II) centers by four carboxylate-O of second NDC-2 (μ4) (Figure S7), which leads to generate a chair form Co2O4C2 repeating unit. Thus, an eight-member Co2O4C2 distorted chair geometry repeats throughout the polymer (). The Co-N(imidazolyl) bond distance is 2.041(3) Å, which is comparable to the reported structure of Co-arylazoimidazole complexes. The Co-N(azo) bond length 2.376(3) Å is longer than Co-N(imidazolyl), which indicates that Co(II) prefers to bind N(imidazolyl), and this is very common in biology. The Co-O bond lengths vary noticeably in the bridging partner: the NDC bridged Co4 motif shows 2.008(3) and 2.016(3) Å, whereas the carboxylato chelated Co2 motif shows 2.235(3) and 2.128(3) Å (). In the chelated motif, both steric and angular strains may cause elongation of the bond length.

In 2, the coordination arrangement is [ZnNO4] and central Zn­(II) lies in a distorted square pyramidal center (τ5 = 0.1603) [for trigonal bipyramidal structure τ5 = 1, while a square pyramidal structure τ5 = 0]. ClPai-Me acts as a monodentate imidazolyl-N donor, the Zn–N distance is 2.024(3) Å, which is comparable with reported data, and the ClC6H4–NN- group is freely suspended. There are three NDC units about the coordination sphere around Zn­(II). One NDC unit bridges two Zn­(II) centers forming chelated unsymmetrical ZnO2 motif (Zn–O lengths: 2.454(2) and 1.994(2) Å); each of the two NDCs is monodentate carboxylato-O donor and bridges four Zn­(II) centers and thus forms an eight-member Zn2O4C2 distorted chair geometry (Figure S7) to generate the coordination polymer (, ).

elements.content: The 2D polymers of 1 and 2 have enhanced supramolecular strength by π···π and C–H···π interactions. In 1 the π···π interaction between two different azoimidazolyl units from each 1D chain () has constructed the 2D supramolecule at a distance 3.972 Å, and in Zn-CP (2) the distance is 3.914 Å. There are also extensive edge-to-face C–H···π interactions in 1 and 2 at a distance of 3.094 and 3.111 Å, respectively, to construct the helical 2D supramolecule (). However, the NDC–2 linker connects the metal ions in compounds 1 and 2 and has been expanded to 3D supramolecular structures.

elements.content: Paramagnetic Co­(II) (d7) complexes are common, and experimental magnetic moment is greater than spin-only value, which is due to orbital contribution. For past few years, magnetic moment and temperature-dependent properties of polynuclear Co­(II) or coordination polymers/MOF are intensively studied. shows the χM T vs T plot of the variable-temperature magnetic properties under an external field of 5000 Oe for [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]·0.5H2O (1). The χM T value of 2.25 cm3 K mol–1 at 5 K increases to the maximum value of 35.5 cm3 K mol–1 at 160 K and slightly decreases to 34.7 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K for four Co­(II) in a NDC2– bonded core of 1. Experimental magnetic moment (μ) per Co­(II) in SBU is 4.17 μB at 300 K, which suggests an isolated Co­(II) ion of S = 3/2. The increased magnetic moment in addition to orbital contribution may be due to spin-superexchange in the dinuclear and tetranuclear carboxylate bridging motif.

elements.content: The redox activities of the coordination polymers (1, 2) in DMF were investigated by cyclic voltammetry at 296 K. The redox potential data referenced to ferrocenium/ferrocene (Fc+/Fc) couple and the cyclic voltammograms are shown in . Complex 1 exhibits one quasi-reversible voltammogram at E 1/2, 0.72 V (ΔE p > 200 mV), whereas the complex 2 is silent within a potential window at the positive potential side. Complex 1 bears redox-sensitive Co­(II), whereas in 2 it is Zn­(II), which has not participated in the redox process. Thus, voltammogram in a refers to the Co­(III)/Co­(II) redox couple. An irreversible cathodic peak observed at −1.65 V for 1 and −1.20 V for 2, but in the case of free ClPai-Me ligand the reversible reduction potential at −1.72 V (Figure S8) which is assigned to reduction of the azo group [-NN-]/[-N–N-]•–.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

The redox activities of the coordination polymers (1, 2) in DMF were investigated by cyclic voltammetry at 296 K. The redox potential data referenced to ferrocenium/ferrocene (Fc+/Fc) couple and the cyclic voltammograms are shown in . Complex 1 exhibits one quasi-reversible voltammogram at E 1/2, 0.72 V (ΔE p > 200 mV), whereas the complex 2 is silent within a potential window at the positive potential side. Complex 1 bears redox-sensitive Co(II), whereas in 2 it is Zn(II), which has not participated in the redox process. Thus, voltammogram in a refers to the Co(III)/Co(II) redox couple. An irreversible cathodic peak observed at -1.65 V for 1 and -1.20 V for 2, but in the case of free ClPai-Me ligand the reversible reduction potential at -1.72 V (Figure S8) which is assigned to reduction of the azo group [-NN-]/[-N-N-]⋅-.

elements.content: Optically stimulated reversible cis/trans isomerization of 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)­imidazoles­(RaaiR / )­in solution in the free ligand phase and mononuclear coordination complexes is known. However, the inclusion of azoimidazole motif in CPs or MOF to act as a photoswitching unit has not been reported previously. For the photochromism of free ClPai-Me, complexes 1 and 2 have been studied in solid and solution phases. ClPai-Me and 2 show photoisomerization and 1 is silent to light induced structural change. The property of photochrome is due to a configurational change about the −NN– group either by torsion or cleavage of double bond. IR spectral analysis in particular to stretching of −NN- (ν ‑NN‑) which appears at 1410 cm–1 of free ligand, ClPai-Me, is shifted to 1396 cm–1 in 1 [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O) and 1408 cm–1 in [Zn­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (2). In compound 1, ClPai-Me serves as a N­(imidazolyl),N­(azo) chelating agent, which may be the reason for lowering of the -NN- stretching frequency. At the same time, the stretching frequency of -NN- in compound 2 remains almost unshifted, which implies noncoordination of the N­(azo) center and p-Cl-C6H4–NN- remains suspended in space (Figure S1). The crystal structure of 2 also shows the presence of pendant free −NN–C6H5–Cl-p(N-azo group) which takes part in active photochromism. The inertness of optical irradiation of 1 may be explained on considering the energy scavenging process of excited species, and out of them two main reasons may be accounted: (i) paramagnetism of Co­(II) complex and (ii) chelation stability of [Co­(-NN–CN-)] motif. Because of unpaired spin of paramagnetic center, Co­(II), the excited energy may be released by spin inversion followed by a large number of L-S coupled states. The chelate structure makes photochromic function stable in one stereochemical form, so torsional motion or cleavage of azo bond followed by inversion is restricted.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromism

Optically stimulated reversible cis/trans isomerization of 1-alkyl-2-(arylazo)imidazoles(RaaiR / )in solution in the free ligand phase and mononuclear coordination complexes is known. However, the inclusion of azoimidazole motif in CPs or MOF to act as a photoswitching unit has not been reported previously. For the photochromism of free ClPai-Me, complexes 1 and 2 have been studied in solid and solution phases. ClPai-Me and 2 show photoisomerization and 1 is silent to light induced structural change. The property of photochrome is due to a configurational change about the -NN- group either by torsion or cleavage of double bond. IR spectral analysis in particular to stretching of -NN- (ν  -NN-) which appears at 1410 cm-1 of free ligand, ClPai-Me, is shifted to 1396 cm-1 in 1 [Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O) and 1408 cm-1 in [Zn(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (2). In compound 1, ClPai-Me serves as a N(imidazolyl),N(azo) chelating agent, which may be the reason for lowering of the -NN- stretching frequency. At the same time, the stretching frequency of -NN- in compound 2 remains almost unshifted, which implies noncoordination of the N(azo) center and p-Cl-C6H4-NN- remains suspended in space (Figure S1). The crystal structure of 2 also shows the presence of pendant free -NN-C6H5-Cl-p(N-azo group) which takes part in active photochromism. The inertness of optical irradiation of 1 may be explained on considering the energy scavenging process of excited species, and out of them two main reasons may be accounted: (i) paramagnetism of Co(II) complex and (ii) chelation stability of [Co(-NN-CN-)] motif. Because of unpaired spin of paramagnetic center, Co(II), the excited energy may be released by spin inversion followed by a large number of L-S coupled states. The chelate structure makes photochromic function stable in one stereochemical form, so torsional motion or cleavage of azo bond followed by inversion is restricted.

elements.content: The absorption spectra of the cis isomers (ClPai-Me and 2) have been obtained by extrapolation of the absorption spectra of a cis-rich mixture. We have collected 1H NMR spectra of ClPai-Me (Figure S5 and Table S1) upon light irradiation (Figure 6), but the spectrum of 2 was not readable to collect the percentage of conversion. It is observed that some new signals have been generated (); those are due to cis-configuration about the -NN- bond of the photochrome, ClPai-Me.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Phase Study

The absorption spectra of the cis isomers (ClPai-Me and 2) have been obtained by extrapolation of the absorption spectra of a cis-rich mixture. We have collected 1H NMR spectra of ClPai-Me (Figure S5 and Table S1) upon light irradiation (Figure 6), but the spectrum of 2 was not readable to collect the percentage of conversion. It is observed that some new signals have been generated (); those are due to cis-configuration about the -NN- bond of the photochrome, ClPai-Me.

elements.content: Because of sparing solubility of 2 in dichloromethane and acetonitrile, the absorption spectrum is recorded in DMF solution and shows bands at 369 and 455 nm. The solution intensity and the absorption band position of 2 remain unchanged keeping the solution for a period of a month or so, which predicts that the structure of the complex remains unperturbed and stable in the experimental condition. The electronic spectral bands in 2 appear in a longer wavelength than that of free ligand, ClPai-Me, 362 and 450 nm, in the same solvent. The bands are consigned to π–π* and n−π* transitions, respectively. The solution of ClPai-Me is then irradiated for the fixed time with UV light at 362 nm followed by a collection of absorption spectrum (); the spectral change is similar to that observed for the trans-to-cis isomerization of 1-methyl-2-(phenylazo)­imidazole. Intense peak at 362 nm decreases along with an increase at the annex portion at 450 nm until a stationary state is reached (photostationary-I, PS-I). Reversal of experiment, i.e., irradiation of visible light of 420 nm to the cis-rich solution increases the intensity of band at 362 nm followed by asmall decrement at 462 nm, and restoration of trans-configuration is recommended (; photostationary-II, PS-II). Similarly, DMF solution of 2 is irradiated at 369 nm, and the spectral change is recorded in , which shows a decrease in intensity and subsequent enhancement of band at 456 nm. Further, the cis-rich component undergoes irradiation at the visible region at 450 nm and recovers its original spectrum (). Thus, reversibility of isomerization process upon optical influence is satisfied. The structure of 2 (Supporting Information, Figure S7) shows pendant -NN–C6H4–Cl, which is supposed to undergo free rotation and isomerizes to the cis-form. The rate of isomerization is faster for ClPai-Me (3.612 × 10–8 s–1) than 2 (0.879 × 10–8 s–1). The quantum yields for the trans-to-cis (ϕt→c) photo isomerization, 0.201 ± 0.003 (ClPai-Me) and 0.071 ± 0.001 (2) are comparable with reported results. In general, increase in mass of the photochrome reduces the rate of isomerization.

elements.content: The UV-light irradiation experiment of 1 does not show any tractable observation and is silent to photo-isomerization. There may be several reasons based on structure, electronic structure, and energy ordering of the participating functions. ClPai-Me is chelated to Co­(II) and the complex is paramagnetic (μ, 4.17 μB at 300 K). Thus, structural rigidity and paramagnetism center may resist photo-isomerization.

elements.content: The cis-to-trans isomerization of ClPai-Me and 2 is carried out at varying temperature, 298–313 K, and the Eyring plots determine the activation energy (E a) 87.95 and 20.18 kJ mol–1 and the activation entropy (ΔS #) −38.06 and −257.20 J mol–1 K–1, respectively for ClPai-Me and 2 (, ). In the complex, E a’s are severely decreased, which means faster cis-to-trans thermal isomerization of the complex. The entropy of activation (ΔS*) is highly negative in the complex than that of free ligand. This is also in support of an increase in molar mass and rotor volume in the complexes.

elements.content: The photostabilities of the compound ClPai-Me in the solid phase were investigated by visual color change and spectroscopic (IR, UV–vis, PXRD, and EPR) measurements. The compounds were exposed in a solar-simulator test chamber for 30 min. Then, the IR spectra of the irradiated compounds were recorded and compared with those of not exposed sample (Figure S9). The irradiation does not cause pronounced changes in the IR spectrum of 2, while IR spectrum of ClPai-Me shows substantial change of ν­(-NN-) at 1410 cm–1 before irradiation and a new stretching appears at 1245 cm–1 after irradiation which may be due to ν­(-N–N-) and may be obtained by a photoexcited reduction process. This modification could be assigned to change in the skeletal vibrations of the -NN- bonds. To investigate further the photostabilities of the complexes, the powder XRD (PXRD) patterns of the compounds were recorded. The PXRD patterns of 2 remain unchanged which support photostability of the complexes at CP phase, but in the case of ClPai-Me ligand shows a significant change in the PXRD pattern after the formation of azo anion radical (Figure S10). In solid state after irradiation with light, ClPai-Me shows an EPR signal (Figure S11) at g av = 2.009 (298 K), which may be due to the formation of azo anion radical and the color changes from yellow to dark red (Figure S12). The EPR signal disappears in solution in DCM. But compound 2 does not show any EPR signal in solid and solution.
elements.clean_text:
Solid (Film) Phase Study

The photostabilities of the compound ClPai-Me in the solid phase were investigated by visual color change and spectroscopic (IR, UV-vis, PXRD, and EPR) measurements. The compounds were exposed in a solar-simulator test chamber for 30 min. Then, the IR spectra of the irradiated compounds were recorded and compared with those of not exposed sample (Figure S9). The irradiation does not cause pronounced changes in the IR spectrum of 2, while IR spectrum of ClPai-Me shows substantial change of ν(-NN-) at 1410 cm-1 before irradiation and a new stretching appears at 1245 cm-1 after irradiation which may be due to ν(-N-N-) and may be obtained by a photoexcited reduction process. This modification could be assigned to change in the skeletal vibrations of the -NN- bonds. To investigate further the photostabilities of the complexes, the powder XRD (PXRD) patterns of the compounds were recorded. The PXRD patterns of 2 remain unchanged which support photostability of the complexes at CP phase, but in the case of ClPai-Me ligand shows a significant change in the PXRD pattern after the formation of azo anion radical (Figure S10). In solid state after irradiation with light, ClPai-Me shows an EPR signal (Figure S11) at g av = 2.009 (298 K), which may be due to the formation of azo anion radical and the color changes from yellow to dark red (Figure S12). The EPR signal disappears in solution in DCM. But compound 2 does not show any EPR signal in solid and solution.

elements.content: a,b illustrates the changes in the electronic absorption spectra of the ClPai-Me and 2, respectively in polystyrene media during irradiation with UV radiation at 360 nm. We see that the polymer films exhibit slightly higher absorption maxima than that of liquid samples, namely, at around 374 and 378 nm, assigned to the π–π* transitions, respectively. The π–π* absorption band decreases in intensity with the irradiation time due to the trans–cis photo-isomerization process of azobenzene moieties. The photostationary state is achieved after 32 min when the conversion is about 60%. It is realized that the cis content of the stationary state was a little lower in polymer film than in solution. A photo-isomerization should be suppressed in solid samples because the free volume around the chromophore is smaller than that of the liquid samples due to a closer packing of the polymeric film.
elements.clean_text: a,b illustrates the changes in the electronic absorption spectra of the ClPai-Me and 2, respectively in polystyrene media during irradiation with UV radiation at 360 nm. We see that the polymer films exhibit slightly higher absorption maxima than that of liquid samples, namely, at around 374 and 378 nm, assigned to the π-π* transitions, respectively. The π-π* absorption band decreases in intensity with the irradiation time due to the trans-cis photo-isomerization process of azobenzene moieties. The photostationary state is achieved after 32 min when the conversion is about 60%. It is realized that the cis content of the stationary state was a little lower in polymer film than in solution. A photo-isomerization should be suppressed in solid samples because the free volume around the chromophore is smaller than that of the liquid samples due to a closer packing of the polymeric film.

elements.content: 2,6-Naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (H2NDC) serves as an organic linker to Co­(II) and Zn­(II) ions along with coordination of (E)-1-methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole, (ClPai-Me), to generate helical coordination polymers [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1) and [Zn­(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (2). ClPai-Me is a monodentate N­(imidazolyl) donor to Zn­(II) (2), and the pendant (-NN–C6H4–Cl) undergoes UV light-induced trans-to-cis isomerization, whereas Co­(II) compound is paramagnetic and optically silent. Photochromism of bonded azoimidazole is reported for the first time for Zn­(II)- coordination polymer in the solution phase. Light irradiation in the film phase (solid) generates azo radical to free ligand ClPai-Me, while complex 2 remains silent in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

2,6-Naphthalene dicarboxylic acid (H2NDC) serves as an organic linker to Co(II) and Zn(II) ions along with coordination of (E)-1-methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)imidazole, (ClPai-Me), to generate helical coordination polymers [Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (1) and [Zn(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (2). ClPai-Me is a monodentate N(imidazolyl) donor to Zn(II) (2), and the pendant (-NN-C6H4-Cl) undergoes UV light-induced trans-to-cis isomerization, whereas Co(II) compound is paramagnetic and optically silent. Photochromism of bonded azoimidazole is reported for the first time for Zn(II)- coordination polymer in the solution phase. Light irradiation in the film phase (solid) generates azo radical to free ligand ClPai-Me, while complex 2 remains silent in the solid state.

cln_elements.content:
(E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)­imidazole (ClPai-Me) had been synthesized and characterized by literature method.

[Co­(∝-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(∝<sub>4</sub>-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(ClPai-Me)]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

ClPai-Me (0.1 mmol), H2NDC (0.1 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) were mixed in a 30 mL vial. Then a mixed solution (9 mL) of methanol/water/DMF was added at an equivalent ratio (1:1:1). The vial was capped well and heated to 100 °C for 72 h, and cooling at the rate of 5 °C/h. The mother liquor was decanted, and the crystals were washed with hexane (15 mL) thrice. Dark black-colored crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air for X-ray study (10 min). Yield: 33.9 mg (∼67%). [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]­·0.5H2O (1) was isolated by filtration. Microanalytical data for (C44H31Cl2Co2N8O9)∞ (1): C, 52.61; H, 3.11; N, 11.15, Found: C, 52.56; H,3.03; N 11.09, IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1609 νas(COO–), 1331 νs(COO–), and 1396 ν­(-NN-) (Supporting Information, Figure S1). The TGA plot of compound 1 confirmed the number of crystallization water molecules, and it is moderately stable up to 330 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 as-synthesized are added in Figure S3.

[Zn­(∝-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(∝<sub>4</sub>-NDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(ClPai-Me)]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was also isolated using the above identical procedure. Yield: 40.6 mg (∼79%). Microanalytical data for (C44H31Cl2N8O9Zn2) ∞ (2): C, 51.94; H, 3.07; N, 11.01, Found: C, 51.89; H, 3.01; N 10.98, IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1615 νas(COO–), 1361 νs(COO–), and 1408 ν­(-NN-) (Supporting Information, Figure S1). The thermal analysis of compound 2 had confirmed the number of crystallization water molecules, and it is moderately stable up to 290 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 2 as-synthesized is added in Figure S4.

Syntheses

(E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)imidazole, (ClPai-Me)

(E)-1-Methyl-2-(p-chlorophenylazo)imidazole (ClPai-Me) had been synthesized and characterized by literature method. 

[Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (1)

ClPai-Me (0.1 mmol), H2NDC (0.1 mmol), and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol) were mixed in a 30 mL vial. Then a mixed solution (9 mL) of methanol/water/DMF was added at an equivalent ratio (1:1:1). The vial was capped well and heated to 100 °C for 72 h, and cooling at the rate of 5 °C/h. The mother liquor was decanted, and the crystals were washed with hexane (15 mL) thrice. Dark black-colored crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air for X-ray study (10 min). Yield: 33.9 mg (~67%). [Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (1) was isolated by filtration. Microanalytical data for (C44H31Cl2Co2N8O9)∞ (1): C, 52.61; H, 3.11; N, 11.15, Found: C, 52.56; H,3.03; N 11.09, IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1609 νas(COO-), 1331 νs(COO-), and 1396 ν(-NN-) (Supporting Information, Figure S1). The TGA plot of compound 1 confirmed the number of crystallization water molecules, and it is moderately stable up to 330 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 as-synthesized are added in Figure S3.

[Zn(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (2)

Compound 2 was also isolated using the above identical procedure. Yield: 40.6 mg (~79%). Microanalytical data for (C44H31Cl2N8O9Zn2) ∞  (2): C, 51.94; H, 3.07; N, 11.01, Found: C, 51.89; H, 3.01; N 10.98, IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1615 νas(COO-), 1361 νs(COO-), and 1408 ν(-NN-) (Supporting Information, Figure S1). The thermal analysis of compound 2 had confirmed the number of crystallization water molecules, and it is moderately stable up to 290 °C (Supporting Information, Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 2 as-synthesized is added in Figure S4.

cln_elements.content:
Paramagnetic Co­(II) (d7) complexes are common, and experimental magnetic moment is greater than spin-only value, which is due to orbital contribution. For past few years, magnetic moment and temperature-dependent properties of polynuclear Co­(II) or coordination polymers/MOF are intensively studied. shows the χM T vs T plot of the variable-temperature magnetic properties under an external field of 5000 Oe for [Co­(∝-NDC)0.5­(∝4-NDC)0.5­(ClPai-Me)]·0.5H2O (1). The χM T value of 2.25 cm3 K mol–1 at 5 K increases to the maximum value of 35.5 cm3 K mol–1 at 160 K and slightly decreases to 34.7 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K for four Co­(II) in a NDC2– bonded core of 1. Experimental magnetic moment (μ) per Co­(II) in SBU is 4.17 μB at 300 K, which suggests an isolated Co­(II) ion of S = 3/2. The increased magnetic moment in addition to orbital contribution may be due to spin-superexchange in the dinuclear and tetranuclear carboxylate bridging motif.

The cis-to-trans isomerization of ClPai-Me and 2 is carried out at varying temperature, 298–313 K, and the Eyring plots determine the activation energy (E a) 87.95 and 20.18 kJ mol–1 and the activation entropy (ΔS #) −38.06 and −257.20 J mol–1 K–1, respectively for ClPai-Me and 2 (, ). In the complex, E a’s are severely decreased, which means faster cis-to-trans thermal isomerization of the complex. The entropy of activation (ΔS*) is highly negative in the complex than that of free ligand. This is also in support of an increase in molar mass and rotor volume in the complexes.

Paramagnetic Co(II) (d7) complexes are common, and experimental magnetic moment is greater than spin-only value, which is due to orbital contribution. For past few years, magnetic moment and temperature-dependent properties of polynuclear Co(II) or coordination polymers/MOF are intensively studied.  shows the χM T vs T plot of the variable-temperature magnetic properties under an external field of 5000 Oe for [Co(∝-NDC)0.5(∝4-NDC)0.5(ClPai-Me)]⋅0.5H2O (1). The χM T value of 2.25 cm3 K mol-1 at 5 K increases to the maximum value of 35.5 cm3 K mol-1 at 160 K and slightly decreases to 34.7 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K for four Co(II) in a NDC2- bonded core of 1. Experimental magnetic moment (μ) per Co(II) in SBU is 4.17 μB at 300 K, which suggests an isolated Co(II) ion of S = 3/2. The increased magnetic moment in addition to orbital contribution may be due to spin-superexchange in the dinuclear and tetranuclear carboxylate bridging motif. 

The cis-to-trans isomerization of ClPai-Me and 2 is carried out at varying temperature, 298-313 K, and the Eyring plots determine the activation energy (E a) 87.95 and 20.18 kJ mol-1 and the activation entropy (ΔS #) -38.06 and -257.20 J mol-1 K-1, respectively for ClPai-Me and 2 (, ). In the complex, E a's are severely decreased, which means faster cis-to-trans thermal isomerization of the complex. The entropy of activation (ΔS*) is highly negative in the complex than that of free ligand. This is also in support of an increase in molar mass and rotor volume in the complexes.
